newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan debt service ratio falls to 52.2 pct.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan debt service ratio falls to 52.2 pct.

text.p: Pakistan's debt service ratio declined to 52.2 percent of export earnings in fiscal 1995/96 (July-June) from 55.7 percent in 1994/95, the State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) said on Thursday.
It said the ratio to foreign exchange earnings also fell to 33.9 percent from 34.9 percent because of static debt service payments and a modest rise in exports and forex earnings.
Pakistan's total external debt was an estimated $28.6 billion at the end of 1995/96, up from $27.07 billion a year earlier, the SBP said in its annual report.
It said foreign debt had expanded sharply and foreign reserves had fallen because of the need to finance Pakistan's large current account deficit for several years.
Medium and short-term debt grew almost three times as fast as long-term debt in 1995/96 and over the past five years.

The bank said the ratio of external debt to gross domestic product fell to 44.1 percent in 1995/96 from 44.8 percent in 1994/95, because nominal GDP growth was higher, and growth in external debt smaller, than in the preceding year.
It said long-term debt amounted to $23.07 billion, or 80.7 percent of the total, while short- and medium-term debt was $5.53 billion, or 19.3 percent of the total.

Debt service payments rose 0.3 percent to $4.336 billion in 1995/96, against a 19.7 percent increase in 1994/95, reflecting lower repayments of principal, especially of short-term loans of less than one year, to commercial banks.
Repayments of principal, which represented 75.1 percent of total debt service payments, fell 1.4 percent to $3.257 billion in 1995/96, against a 21.4 percent increase in 1994/95.
Interest payments, rising 5.8 percent to an estimated $1.079 billion, constituted 24.9 percent of total external debt service payments, the central bank report said.
